text: For example I often hear “mi mama” (my mother) in Spanish even if one sibling talks to another sibling, which sounds very weird when your own language requires the use of “our mother” in this situation

text: Yes! Hungarians do the same thing (at least the  ones I know heh)

text: In Japanese it’s common to refer to yourself in the third person, as far as I understand

text: I gripe on my cousins for doing that cuz it's suuuuper weird

text: Interesting, though I've realised when speaking to a friend (which we share the same supervisor), addressing our supervisor using his name or we would say "your supervisor" but never "my supervisor" or "our supervisor"
